title: What was the first funk recording? Anything prior to James Brown? - Quora

response.answer_text: 20th Century Noise Hard bop music is sometimes referred to as funky jazz. Back in the late 1950s, there was a movement away from austere sound of cool jazz. Musicians wanted to be more •“Afro-centric.” This new style featured long stretches of melody over the same chord and used rock, soul, and R & B in its rhythm sections, à la Ray Charles. One of the first tunes that appeared in this styles is “Moanin’” by Art Blakey & the Jazz Messengers.  Another that really defines the style is “The Sidewinder” by Lee Morgan.  While funky jazz, or hard bop, was a fresh take on jazz, it was and still is derided by many jazz purists. These tunes definitely predated James Brown.

I'm inclined to say Dave Bartholomew and Professor Longhair were the first composers to think along funk lines.  They were both pioneers in the New Orleans sound that really kick-started the funk movement with 1950s R&B.  Give a listen to two 1949 songs: "Carnival Day (Bartholomew) and "Mardi Gras In New Orleans" (Longhair).  One of those two or both could be considered the first funk recordings.
